Fig. 1 (a) Wide-angle XRD patterns, (b) FT-IR spectra, (c) N2 physisorption isotherms, (d) pore width distribution of supports. Fig. 2 TEM images and Ni particle size distribution of catalysts: (a) Ni/YD-5, (b) Ni/YD-10, (c) Ni/YD-15, (d) Ni/YD-20, (e) Ni/YD-30, (f) Ni/DMSNs. Fig. 3 TEM images of YD composites and DMSNs: (a) YD-5, (b) YD-10, (c) YD-15, (d) YD-20, (e) YD-30, (f) DMSNs, (g) EDS images of Ni/YD-20, (h-i) HRTEM of Ni/YD-20. Fig. 4 (a) Adsorption patterns of TMB at 25 °C, (b) adsorption rates of TMB in catalysts. Fig. 5 (a) Py-IR spectra after desorbing at 200 °C, (b) Py-IR spectra after desorbing at 350 °C, (c) NH3-TPD spectra of catalysts. Fig. 6 (a) H2-TPR profiles of series catalysts, (b) H2-TPD patterns of series catalysts, (c) TG-DTA profiles of series spent catalysts. Fig. 7 (a) XPS full spectra of series catalysts, (b) XPS fitting spectrogram of series catalysts, (c) Raman spectra of the oxide catalysts. Fig. 8 (a) HCK conversion of series catalysts at different temperature, (b) Reaction kinetic parameters and TOF values over series catalysts (Reaction conditions: T = 250–440 °C, P = 4 MPa, H2/naphthalene = 1000 (volume ratio) and WHSV = 6 h−1; 1 g catalyst). Fig. 9 Products distribution of naphthalene HCK at different reaction temperature over (a) Ni/YD-5, (b) Ni/YD-10, (c) Ni/YD-15, (d) Ni/YD-20, (e) Ni/YD-30, (f) Ni/DMSNs, (g) Ni/Y, (h) HCK of naphthalene on various systems for the production of BTX (refer to Table S2) (Reaction conditions: T = 360–440 °C, P = 4 MPa, H2/naphthalene = 1000 (volume ratio) and WHSV = 6 h−1; 1 g catalyst; Note: naphthalene refers to the unconverted reactant.). Research article Preparation and optimization of dendritic Ni/Y-silica composite catalysts for naphthalene hydrocracking to BTX Xiaoyang Kong Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Zhentao Liu Writing – review & editing Investigation Data curation Yutong Zou Visualization Investigation Data curation Chunya Wang Writing – review & editing Methodology Investigation Chunming Xu Resources Investigation Data curation Xilong Wang Writing – review & editing Investigation ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum (Beijing), Beijing 102249, PR China State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing China University of Petroleum (Beijing) Beijing 102249 PR China State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum (Beijing), Beijing 102249, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A novel hierarchical composite material (YD) is engineered via nano-assembly of Y microcrystals and dendritic mesoporous silica nanospheres (DMSNs), serving as superior supports for highly selective naphthalene hydrocracking catalysts (Ni/YD). The three-dimensional center-radial pore architecture of DMSNs shortens molecular diffusion paths and enhances the accessibility of catalytic active sites. Controlled incorporation of Y nanocrystals enriches acidic sites and optimizes metal-support interaction. Moreover, [Ni(en)3](NO3)2 is used as the nickel precursor further improves metal dispersion, maximizing hydrogenation sites. Consequently, the optimized Ni/YD achieves 93.4 % naphthalene conversion with >65 % BTX yield, exhibiting superior kinetics (reaction rate constant of 1.9 h−1 and turnover frequency of 33.7 h−1). Based on the proposed reaction pathway, appropriate acidity, open dendritic pores and highly dispersed Ni species synergistically promote the isomerization-cracking route selectivity and directed hydrocracking of naphthalene. Keywords Dendritic Ni/YD catalysts Dendritic pore structure Acid site Naphthalene Selective hydrocracking Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The elevated polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) content in catalytic cracking light cycle oil (LCO) contradicts the requirement for clean diesel fuel to reduce the content of PAHs (no more than 7 %) [1–3]. The conversion of LCO into light aromatics (i.e., benzene, toluene and xylene (BTX)) has emerged as a strategic approach to maximize the economic benefits while addressing environmental concerns [4,5]. Three-dimensional 12-membered rings Y zeolite supported transition metal catalysts demonstrate great potential toward BTX during PAHs hydrocracking (HCK) process [6,7]. Although the regular topology and abundant acid sites of Y zeolite endow it with good shape selectivity and cracking ring-opening ability for reactants, the aperture size of Y zeolite micropores (0.74 × 0.74 nm) is smaller than or close to the kinetic diameter of PAHs, which affects its mass transfer and is susceptible to side reactions or catalyst deactivation [8,9]. Recently, dendritic mesoporous silica nanospheres (DMSNs) with radial pore channels, short transmission distances and high surface areas have been proven to be of great advantage in catalytic hydrogenation process [10–14]. But the pure silica composition of DMSNs determined its weak acidity and mismatched metal-support interaction (MSI), resulting in the poor cracking and ring-opening of PAHs [15]. Considering the abundant Brønsted acid sites, microporous structure of Y zeolite and tunable pore size, pure silicon-based properties of DMSNs, designing and developing high performance HCK catalysts based on DMSNs and Y zeolite through a simple, green and feasible nano-assembly method has significant industrial value [16]. Ni-supported catalysts are widely utilized in HCK owing to their cost-effectiveness, strong poisoning resistance and high hydrogenation activity [17–19]. Tailoring metal precursors during preparation enhances nickel dispersion and sintering resistance [20,21], yielding small, highly dispersed Ni nanoparticles that expose abundant active sites, thereby boosting the initial hydrogenation activity and reaction rates for naphthalene. On the other hand, HCK is mostly carried out at high temperatures (300–500 °C), high H2 pressures (∼6 MPa) and prolonged reaction time (∼0.5 h−1) to achieve high yield of light aromatics, the reaction conditions are relatively harsh [22–25]. Therefore, bifunctional catalyst with high HCK activity and light aromatics yield under mild conditions is beneficial to energy saving and consumption reduction in industrial production. In the present work, Y nanocrystals were incorporated into the structure of DMSNs and a novel Y-DMSNs-x (YD-x, x represents SiO2/Al2O3) composites with tunable acidity and morphologies were synthesized. The corresponding Ni/YD-x catalysts were prepared by using [Ni(en)3](NO3)2 complexes to enhance metal dispersion. The optimized Ni/YD catalyst exhibit the optimal HCK activity (>90 %) and BTX yield (>65 %) under relatively mild reaction conditions (H2 pressure: 4 MPa, WHSV: 6 h−1), as well as high turnover frequency (TOF) and reaction rate constant (kHCK). Furthermore, the possible reaction mechanism of naphthalene HCK of series of Ni/YD-x catalysts were proposed. This study demonstrates that combining DMSNs with Y zeolite will be one of the promising and valuable candidates for industrial HCK applications. 2 Experimental section 2.1 YD supports and Ni/YD catalysts preparation Y zeolite seeds is prepared from a gel composition: 8 Na2O: 0.7 Al2O3: 10 SiO2: 160 H2O. 2 g sodium hydroxide (NaOH, 98 %) and 0.57 g sodium aluminate (NaAlO2, 98 %) dissolve in 4 g deionized water to form solution A, and solution B is prepared by mixing of 10 g colloidal silica (30 wt% SiO2, pH = 9.8) with 0.92 g NaOH and 3.4 g deionized water, then solution B is placed in an oven at 100 °C for 0.5 h to obtain water clear suspension. The mixture of A and B is stirred at 350 rpm for 24 h at room temperature and pH is measured as 13.4, after hydrothermal crystallization at 120 °C for 2 h, the Y seeds are synthesized by filtration and drying. The YD micro-mesoporous composites are prepared by a nano-assembly method: 0.82 g triethanolamine (TEA, ≥99.0 %), 4.56 g cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB, 99 %) and 2.02 g sodium salicylate (NaSal, 99 %) are dissolved in 300 g deionized water under 80 °C water bath temperatures, continuously stirring at 350 rpm until the mixture solution is homogeneous, and 48.0 g tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, 98 %) is slowly added. Subsequently, different amounts of Y crystal seeds (40.08, 10.18, 5.82, 4.08, 2.55 g) are added separately into the above solution and keep stir at 350 rpm for 2 h, and the pH of solutions are measured as 10.8, 9.7, 9.5, 9.4 and 9.3, respectively. Pure DMSNs is the same as the above synthesis method but without the addition of Y seeds and pH is measured as 9.6. The mixed solution is transferred to Teflon bottle and heat for 4 h at 100 °C, series of YD-x (x represents the SiO2/Al2O3 molar ratios of 5, 10, 15, 20, 30) supports are obtained after filtration, washing and drying. Based on previous relevant research [26], a metal loading of 15 wt% is selected. Ni/YD-x catalysts containing 15 wt% Ni are prepared by ethylenediamine-assisted impregnation procedure: Ni(NO3)2·6H2O is dissolved in deionized water, and then C2H8N2·H2O is added slowly dropwise with stirring at 35 °C in the water bath for 10 min to form [Ni(en)3](NO3)2 precursor, and the impregnated catalysts are dried overnight at 60 °C and calcined at 480 °C for 4 h to obtain. 2.2 Characterization of the YD supports and Ni/YD catalysts The details of characterization methods (i.e., X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscope (TEM), Scanning electron microscopy (SEM), N2 adsorption–desorption, Thermogravimetric analysis (TG), Inductively Coupled Plasma Emission Spectroscopy (ICP-OES), H2-pulse adsorption and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) characterization) are introduced in the Supporting Information. 2.3 HCK performance evaluation The catalytic activities are evaluated using cyclohexane solution containing 5 wt% naphthalene as model compound. The solubility decreases in the order of cyclohexane > n-octane > n-dodecane > n-heptane at room temperature and pressure, while the market price is in the reverse order. Considering the solubility of naphthalene in four solvents and solvents price, cyclohexane is chosen as solvent. Most importantly, cyclohexane is not involved in the reaction. HCK reactions is performed in a fix-bed reactor loaded with 1.0 g catalyst (40–60 mesh). First, the catalyst is reduced for 4 h under a H2 atmosphere (450 °C, 4 MPa, H2 flow rate of 100 mL min−1), and the HCK reactions are performed under conditions of total pressure of 4 MPa, H2/Oil ratio of 1000, weight hour space velocity (WHSVs) of 6 h−1 and reaction temperature in the range of 360–440 °C. The collected liquid products are analyzed by Agilent 7890B gas chromatography/5977A mass spectrometry (GC/MS) instrument. The corresponding gas products are analyzed by gas chromatograph (Agilent 7890A) with a FID detector equipped with a HP-Plot Q capillary column and the gas weight is considered to be the difference in mass between the injected feedstock and the collected liquid products [6]. The HCK conversions and BTX yield are calculated according to the equations [27]: (1) x HCK ( % ) = n F - n P n F × 100 % (2) y BTX ( % ) = n BTX n F × 100 % where nF and nP is the naphthalene content in the feedstock and reaction products, respectively. nBTX is the BTX content in the products. Additionally, the experimental error is determined by blank experiment using cyclohexane as feedstock under the same reaction conditions. and there are no side reactions of cyclohexane and the mass of liquid products remain basically unchanged before and after reactions. The naphthalene HCK reaction is carried out in the constant pressure and excessive hydrogen atmosphere, so the reaction can be regarded as a pseudo-first-order reaction [28,29]. The kHCK (h−1) and TOF (h−1) are calculated by following formula [30]: (3) k HCK = F m ln 1 1 - x HCK (4) TOF = F × x HCK × M Ni m × w Ni × D Ni where F is the feeding rate of the reactant (g h−1), xHCK is the total conversion of naphthalene, m is the catalyst mass (g), wNi is the Ni loading in the catalyst (% determined by ICP characterization), and DNi is the Ni dispersion degree (% tested by the H2-pulse adsorption). The activation energy (Ea, kJ mol−1) is calculated based on the Arrhenius equation [31]: (5) ln k HCK = - E a RT + ln A where R, T and A is the Gas constant, reaction temperature and the preexponential factor, respectively. 3 Results 3.1 Synthetic mechanism of YD supports The reasonable synthetic mechanism for YD-x materials is depicted in Scheme 1 . Firstly, CTAB and Nasal were aggregated under the catalytic effect of TEA to form guided micelles with hydrophobic ends facing inward and hydrophilic ends facing outward. Subsequently, the CTAB micelles and added TEOS hydrolyzes were self-assembled into silicified micelles, and the Y seeds with high Al content were easily penetrated into CTAB micelles through bonding with the surface Si-O-Al bonds. Finally, the silicified micelles further assemble into aggregates, inducing the center-radial structure of YD composites. Along with the penetration process, the pore sizes of YD composites decrease and tend to form stable spherical particles. 3.2 Characterization of supports and catalysts 3.2.1 Structure properties and pore structure The wide angle XRD and FT-IR spectra of YD supports are shown in Fig. 1 (a-b). It can be observed that the YD-5 composite presents strong characteristic diffraction peaks of Y zeolites, and the characteristic peaks at 2θ = 6.2°, 10.1°, 15.6° and 23.6° are attributed to the (1 1 1), (2 2 0), (3 3 1) and (5 3 3) crystal planes of Y seeds [32], indicating that Y is successfully introduced into the composites. The intensity of characteristic peaks decrease gradually with the decrease of Y crystal seeds, and the relative crystallinity (RC) is calculated from the XRD characteristic peak areas using the (5 3 3) crystal plane as a reference and listed in Table 2 [33]. The RC of YD composites decreases significantly as the SiO2/Al2O3 molar ratio increases. This decline is primarily attributed to insufficient nucleation sites, resulting from the reduced addition of Y crystal seeds, coupled with restricted crystal growth due to the tight coating by DMSNs. These effects manifest as a significant reduction in the intensity of characteristic peaks in XRD patterns [34,35]. Besides, the effect of DMSNs after introducing Y microcrystals are explored, and all samples in the FT-IR spectra exhibit characteristic peaks attributed to Si-O-Si vibrations at 460 cm−1, 804 cm−1, 979 cm−1 and 1080 cm−1. Compared with DMSNs, series of YD supports show the characteristic peak of double six-membered rings (D6R) opening vibration at 570 cm−1, which is characteristics of faujasite [10,11,36]. The most obvious characteristic peak at 570 cm−1 of Y zeolite also suggests a good combination of Y and DMSNs. Supports with open pore channels and large surface areas are beneficial for the efficient utilization of active metals and diffusion of naphthalene molecules in HCK process. Fig. 1(c–d) display that all the composites possess large H3 hysteresis loops and exhibit IV type isotherms of mesoporous materials, with a wide pore size distribution (1–80 nm) and a broad peak near 30 nm, which is consistent with the center-radial structure of DMSNs. The results of the textural properties and pore size distribution of series supports are listed in Table 1 . The specific surface area and RC of the series of supports progressively decrease with increasing DMSNs content. According to Fig. S2(a-b), the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of all Ni/YD catalysts exhibit reduced hysteresis loops and wider pore size distributions. This behavior stems from the combined effects of: (1) pore blockage by NiO nanoparticles (3.7–9.1 nm), (2) partial collapse of the mesopore walls within the amorphous DMSNs during calcination, (3) the formation of smaller reduced Ni metal particles (3.2–7.0 nm). Fig. S1 presents the XRD spectra of Ni supported catalysts, and the characteristic peaks of (1 1 1), (200) and (2 2 0) crystal planes attributed to NiO appear at 37.3°, 43.3° and 62.9° (JCPDS card No. 78-0423), respectively [37,38]. The significantly higher NiO peak intensity observed in Ni/Y arises from the microporous structure of the Y zeolite, which restricts metal diffusion and distribution. This limitation leads to the formation of larger NiO particles (9.1 nm) with low dispersion (11.1 %). In contrast, Ni/YD catalysts exhibit broader and weaker XRD peaks. This difference is attributed to the open pore structure and high external surface area of YD (Table 1), which enhance metal dispersion and promote the formation of smaller, well-distributed NiO particles [39]. 3.2.2 Microstructure and morphology Fig. S4 and Fig. 3 show the physical morphology and microstructure of DMSNs and series YD-x supports. According to SEM images, the YD-x supports are composed of uniform spheres with a particle diameter of approximately 200 nm, with a wrinkled surface that is almost unaffected by the content of Y seeds. Demonstrated by the TEM images of YD composites, YD-x materials exhibit dendritic pore structure dispersed from the inside out, which could facilitate the mass transfer of reactive molecules and enhance the accessibility of active metal species. As shown in Fig. 2 (a–f), compared with the supports, the loading of the active metal does not disrupt the original morphology. The metal particles on the series catalysts present smaller sizes (Table 2). As depicted in Fig. 3(g), Si, O, Al and Ni are uniformly dispersed on Ni/YD-20, and show a clear partitioning of dendritic elements, further confirming that the well integration of Al species from Y seeds into the DMSNs framework. Moreover, the HRTEM (Fig. 3(h-i)) of Ni/YD-20 exhibited Ni (1 1 1) and Ni (200) planes attributed to Ni species, corresponding to the lattice spacing of 0.203 nm and 0.175 nm, respectively [37,40], which is consistent with the wide-angle XRD results of catalysts. It can be observed from Fig. 3(i) that there are obvious lattice stripes of Ni species on the surface of Ni/YD-20 catalyst, indicating that the catalyst possesses high reduction degree, good dispersion and small metal particle, which is attributed to the special center-radial structure of DMSNs and the modulation of MSI by introducing Y seeds. To investigate the mass transfer performance of dendritic porous composites, the diffusion and adsorption properties of 1,3,5-trimethylbenzene (TMB) over Ni/Y and Ni/YD-20 at 25 °C are characterized by Intelligent Gravimetric Analyze (IGA). As shown in Fig. 4 (a), TMB undergoes rapid adsorption on Ni/YD-20 via capillary condensation within P/P0 = 0.2–0.8, exhibiting higher adsorption capacity than Ni/Y. This indicates enhanced accessibility to surface sites facilitated by the mesopores. Concurrently, Fig. 4(b) reveals a significantly higher D/L2 value for Ni/YD-20 (1.2 × 10−2 s−1) compared to Ni/Y (4.2 × 10−3 s−1), verifying that dendritic mesochannels promote mass transfer diffusion [41–43]. These results collectively demonstrate that incorporating mesopores in Ni/YD-x catalysts simultaneously enhances reactant adsorption/diffusion while minimizing diffusion limitations, thereby improving reaction kinetics and catalytic activity. 3.2.3 Surface acidity properties of Ni/YD catalysts The surface acid properties of the catalysts are analyzed by Py-IR spectra as shown in Fig. 5 (a and b). The medium/strong acid and total acid amounts are obtained at 350 °C and 200 °C, respectively [44–46]. Ni/DMSNs exhibits predominantly Lewis (L) acid sites with only a small number of Brønsted (B) acid sites. For Ni/YD catalysts, the B acid centers originate from B acidic hydroxyl groups and framework aluminum species, corresponding to Si–O(H)-Al and framework Al-OH groups at 3629 cm−1, 3689 cm−1 in OH-IR (Fig. S5), and the L acid centers originate from surface hydroxyl groups, corresponding to extra-framework Al-OH groups at 3650 cm−1 in OH-IR [47,48]. It can be seen that the amount of B and L acids decrease with increasing SiO2/Al2O3 molar ratios (Table 3 ), which is because as the amount of Y seeds decrease, fewer Si–O–Al bonds and more terminal isolated Si–OH groups are formed, further leading to the decrease in surface acidity and a gradual enhancement of the peak intensity at 3741 cm−1 in OH-IR [49]. B acid sites serve as the primary active centers for tetralin isomerization and C–C bond cleavage. Their spatial distribution on the support governs the selectivity towards BTX precursors (indene/alkylbenzene). Meanwhile, L acid sites synergistically promote hydrogen activation with metal sites, effectively lowering the isomerization energy barrier and stabilizing carbocation intermediates [7,50–53]. As depicted in Fig. 5(c), NH3-TPD was performed to accurately determine the acid strength and amount of catalysts, and the temperatures of 100–250 °C, 250–400 °C and 400–600 °C correspond to the weak, medium and strong acids of the catalysts, respectively [54]. The introduction of Y seeds increases the number of surface hydroxyl groups forming acid sites, which in turn affects the distribution of acid sites in the catalysts and enhances the acid strength. Appropriate acidity can optimize the MSI, promoting the uniform dispersion of active metals on the supports, which ultimately influences the HCK reaction path [55,56]. Notably, Ni/YD-20 exhibits the lowest strong acid content among all Ni/YD catalysts. This is primarily because the acidity of catalyst predominantly consists of weak and medium acid sites. This distribution is confirmed by the enhanced peak intensity at 3650 cm−1 in the OH-IR spectra, attributed to extra-framework Al-OH groups [11,57]. Furthermore, the reduced strong acidity also arises from the partial coverage of B acid centers by smaller Ni nanoparticles (3.8 nm) at fixed loading and the high Si/Al ratio [58,59]. 3.2.4 Metal-support interaction of Ni/YD catalysts The redox performance of prepared catalysts is measured by H2-TPR as shown in Fig. 6 (a) and the corresponding H2 consumption capacity are listed in Table 2. All oxide catalysts present two strong reduction peaks in the range of 250–450 °C and 450–700 °C, corresponding to the reduction of different nickel species. The peaks within the range of 250–450 °C are attributed to the reduction of NiO with weaker MSI, and the corresponding metal particles are usually larger, whereas the peaks within 450–700 °C are assigned as the reduction of NiO with stronger MSI [60,61]. As the content of Y seeds decreases, the proportion of low-temperature reduction peaks decreases, and the high-temperature reduction peaks gradually shift towards the high temperature direction. This indicates a decrease in the content of large particles NiO with weak interaction forces and an increase in highly dispersed Ni species on the catalysts. However, the Al content of catalyst also directly affects the dispersion state of active metal, and catalysts with lower acidity provide fewer anchoring sites for NiO, resulting in the larger particles [62]. Ni/YD-20 not only possesses moderate MSI, but also exhibits the high H2 consumption capacity, which makes active metal species easy to reduce and disperse. The dissociation of H2 over series catalysts is further explored by H2-TPD. As can be seen from Fig. 6(b), the desorption of hydrogen on all catalysts can be divided into two regions. The desorption peak after 550 °C is attributed to the hydrogen spillover effect, and the three desorption peaks before 550 °C belong to hydrogen species with weak binding to metal (40–150 °C), the desorption of hydrogen species bound to Niδ+ (150–220 °C) and the desorption of hydrogen adsorbed on different nickel sites (220–500 °C), respectively [63,64]. The activated hydrogen species content of Ni/YD catalysts decreases with the sequence of Ni/YD-5 > Ni/YD-10 > Ni/YD-20 > Ni/YD-15 > Ni/YD-30, arising from enhanced MSI that promotes hydrogen dissociation and spillover, yet concurrently elevates reduction temperatures, thereby suppressing hydrogen activation and dissociation at metal sites. Therefore, the order of activated hydrogen species content on the catalysts is a result of the combination of both effects [65]. Additionally, the results from TG analysis indicate the resistance to carbon deposition of catalysts. It can be seen in Fig. 6(c) that Ni/Y exhibits a higher total mass loss rate than Ni/YD-x catalysts, illustrating that more carbon is deposed on the surface of the Ni/Y, which is probably due to the microporous structure restricting the diffusion of reactive macromolecules and aggregating at the microporous orifice [66]. On the other hand, the mass loss rate on Ni/YD-x catalysts decreased with decreasing acid strength and enlarged pore size, further demonstrating that the open pore structure and suitable acid distribution are the key to optimize MSI and improve reaction activity. 3.2.5 Chemical state analysis of active phase The Ni chemical state and type on the series catalysts are characterized by XPS. The Ni 2p XPS spectra are shown in Fig. 7 (b), and the peak fitting results are listed in Table S1. The Ni 2p XPS spectra of catalysts contain three well-resolved peaks, which are attributed to the Ni 2p3/2 peaks of Ni0 species (∼853 eV), Ni2+ species (∼856 eV) and satellite peaks (∼861 eV), respectively [67]. With the decrease of Y seeds addition, the peak positions of Ni0 species tend to move to the position with higher binding energy, indicating that electron transfer occurred between Ni clusters and adjacent acid sites, forming electron-deficient state of the metal [68]. The Ni/YD-x catalysts exhibit higher Ni0 species content compared to Ni/Y and Ni/DMSNs. This is attributed to their dendritic pore structure, which effectively disperses metal particles, enhancing active sites exposure and facilitating reduction. Notably, although other Ni/YD-x catalysts show higher dispersion and smaller particle sizes, Ni/YD-5 possesses the highest Ni0 content among all catalysts. This superior performance arises from its lower reduction peak temperature (Fig. 6(a)), promoting facile metal reduction, and the stabilizing effect of adjacent B acid sites (Table 3) on Ni0 species through electrostatic interactions during the reduction process [69]. From the XPS full spectra of catalysts shown in Fig. 7(a), Ni, O and Si elements are identified on all catalysts, confirming that Ni has been successfully supported on the series catalysts. The peaks of Al element are observed in all samples except Ni/DMSNs, and the peak intensity is enhanced with the Y seeds addition, suggesting that the uniform distribution and successful incorporation of Y units throughout the DMSNs materials. The Raman spectra of series oxide catalysts are shown in Fig. 7(c) for observing the chemical state of the Ni active phase. The series catalysts did not exhibit obvious characteristic peaks, and only a vibrational characteristic peak attributed to NiO appeared at 510 cm−1, which is considered as the precursor of Ni0 species [70–72]. Notably, the metal loading on all catalysts is almost same from the theoretical value (Table 2), suggesting that YD composite catalysts indeed have higher metal reduction degree. 3.3 Catalytic activity evaluation 3.3.1 HCK performance of Ni/YD catalysts The HCK performance of Ni/YD catalysts for naphthalene is evaluated at different temperatures (360–440 °C), as shown in Fig. 8 (a). The series catalysts exhibit high conversion of naphthalene, almost all of which are higher than 90 % at 400 °C or 420 °C, and the differences in HCK activity is small with temperature. Notably, the conversion on Ni/YD-5 abnormally decreases gradually with increasing temperature. This is because of its excessive hydrogenation activity at low temperatures and cracking activity at high temperatures, which can be inferred from the intermediates (such as tetralin, indene and light alkanes) generated in the stage in Fig. 9 (a). In order to investigate the effect of the structure and acid properties on the HCK performance over the composite catalysts, the reaction products at different temperatures obtained from the series of catalysts are analyzed and shown in Fig. 9(a–g). The reaction products mainly contain target products (BTX), intermediate products (tetralin, alkylbenzene and indene) and by-products (decalin, light alkane, condensation products and others), of which light alkanes mainly refer to small molecular alkanes with carbon number less than cyclohexane, condensation products are mostly heavy aromatics with molecular weight greater than naphthalene, such as 1-methylnaphthalene and biphenyl, and others are mainly products that cannot be clearly defined between cyclohexane and naphthalene. The yield of BTX shows an overall trend of first increasing and then decreasing with the increase of reaction temperature, because HCK is a reversible endothermic reaction. At low temperatures, the hydrogenation activity of active metal is strong, high proportion of tetralin and decalin are generated in the products, and cracking ability of acid becomes strong at high temperature, more condensation products or lighter alkanes are generated. Compared with Ni/DMSNs and Ni/Y, the series of Ni/YD-x catalysts generally present higher BTX selectivity, and the BTX yield is negatively correlated with the yield of others, indicating that open channels, appropriate acidity and metal hydrogenation activity are conducive to improving the HCK activity, affecting the selection of reaction pathways, and thus promoting the generation of BTX. In addition, Ni/YD-20 exhibits the highest BTX yield at relatively low HCK conversion compared with catalysts under similar reaction conditions in literature (Fig. 9(h)). The superior catalytic performance of Ni/YD-20 is mainly the results of synergistic effect of unique dendritic center-radial structure, suitable acidity, optimal MSI and ultrafine Ni nanoparticles active phase. Dendritic divergent pores facilitate the diffusion and mass transfer of reactants, effectively improve the accessibility of naphthalene to the Ni species and provide abundant hydrogenation sites. The mild medium-strong acid sites reduce the occurrence of cracking side reactions and facilitate the formation of hydrogen spillover, thus promoting the adsorption of intermediates (alkylbenzene, indene and other aromatic compounds) on the supports and conversion to BTX. The chemical composition state of Ni species is associated with the MSI, suitable MSI makes the active metal easier to be reduced (H2 consumption of 3998 μmol g−1), suppress carbon deposition on the supports and minimize the size change of the metal particles before (3.9 nm) and after (3.8 nm) reduction, which is beneficial for improving hydrogenation activity. For an in-depth understanding of the intrinsic catalytic performance of the prepared Ni/YD-x catalysts, the reaction rate constants kHCK and turnover frequency values (TOF) are calculated and given in Fig. 8(b). The Ni/YD-x series catalysts demonstrate superior kHCK and TOF values compared to Ni/Y and Ni/DMSNs. This enhanced performance stems from the synergistic modulation of optimal acid sites distribution and hierarchical porosity: acidic sites facilitate C–C bond cleavage, while mesopores enhance mass diffusion. Moreover, Ni/YD-20 exhibits a significantly lower activation energy than Ni/Y (Fig. S6), indicating that its dendritic structure results in a lower energy barrier and facilitates hydrogenation. Notably, Ni/YD-30 achieves the highest kHCK and TOF values due to its low acid density (minimizing side reactions) and large pore volume (optimizing diffusion), demonstrating excellent initial naphthalene hydrogenation ability but poor isomerization performance. In contrast, Ni/YD-20 delivers the maximal BTX yield. This is attributed to its balanced acid strength and optimized MSI, which significantly promotes the directed cracking pathway: tetralin → indene → alkylbenzene. The stability of Ni/YD-20 catalyst was tested and no significant decrease in activity and selectivity of the catalyst was found after continuous use for 60 h (Fig. S7), which indicates that the catalyst possesses good catalytic activity under HCK reaction conditions. Moreover, the dispersion of Ni on the spent catalyst measured by H2-pulse adsorption is 16.5 %, which is not significantly reduced compared to fresh catalyst (18.8 %), suggesting that no obvious aggregation of metal particles occurred after the catalytic reaction. 3.3.2 HCK mechanism of naphthalene to BTX The typical liquid product types and corresponding gas products on Ni/DMSNs catalyst are shown in Figs. S8–S9. Combined with the product distribution results on series catalysts, the reaction pathway of naphthalene HCK to BTX is speculated, as shown in Fig. 10 . First, gaseous naphthalene molecules undergo partial hydrogenation (HYD) saturation to tetralin on metal sites. Subsequently, L acid sites preferentially adsorb and activate the C–H bonds in the saturated ring of tetralin, forming an intermediate species. This intermediate migrates to adjacent B acid sites, where protonation generates a carbocation intermediate. The carbocation then undergoes ring contraction to form indene. This process can be further enhanced through synergistic metal–acid catalysis, generating 1(2)-methylindane via isomerization (ISO) and cracking reactions. Finally, indene undergoes cracking/ring-opening (RO) reactions at B acid centers within the pore channels of support, producing alkylbenzenes with varying alkyl chain lengths. These alkylbenzenes ultimately yield BTX through dealkylation or cracking reactions. However, under the influence of metal–acid functional imbalance of the catalysts and varying reaction conditions, various side reactions may occur, leading to a decrease in BTX yield. At high temperatures, naphthalene is susceptible to alkylation catalyzed by strong acid sites to form 1(2)-methylnaphthalene or condensation to heavy aromatic compounds such as biphenyl. As a key intermediate, strong HYD activity of active metal can cause deep HYD of tetralin to decalin, while strong acidity can lead to excessive cracking into alkylcycloalkanes with varying side-chain lengths. In addition, the key to improve BTX yield is to prevent further conversion of target products into light alkanes or olefins of C1-C4 (methane, ethane and propylene, etc.). The adsorption and activation capacities for reactants are different over series catalysts due to the differences in structure, acid sites distribution and metal dispersion. Compared with Ni/PY, Ni/YD-x exhibit mild acidity and suitable B/L ratios, which is conducive to the generation of hydrogen spillover effect and optimize MSI. Moreover, the superior mass transfer and diffusion performance can effectively promote selective HCK of naphthalene. 4 Conclusions Series dendritic Ni/YD-x micro-mesoporous composite catalysts with different morphologies and acidity are prepared by a facile method for efficient selective HCK of naphthalene. The construction of central-radial dendritic structure not only reduce the diffusion resistance of reactants in the channels, but provide more adsorption and activation sites. By decorating Y microcrystals into the structure of DMSNs, acidic sites are introduced to facilitate the hydrogen spillover effect, which harmonizes the balance of HYD and ISO-cracking reactivity and favors the generation of BTX precursors. Furthermore, the addition of ethylenediamine improves the dispersion of active metal, promotes the formation of more reducing Ni0 species and optimizes MSI. Overall, the optimized Ni/YD catalyst shows superior BTX yield of 68.1 % and HCK activity of 93.4 % under relatively mild reaction conditions with the WHSV of 6 h−1 and H2 pressure of 4 MPa, also shows high kHCK and TOF values due to the combined merits of the open dendritic channels, suitable acidity, highly dispersed active metal phases and optimal MSI. This work presents new insights for the industrial development of efficient HCK catalysts to produce high-value chemicals. coredata.dc:description: A novel hierarchical composite material (YD) is engineered via nano-assembly of Y microcrystals and dendritic mesoporous silica nanospheres (DMSNs), serving as superior supports for highly selective naphthalene hydrocracking catalysts (Ni/YD). The three-dimensional center-radial pore architecture of DMSNs shortens molecular diffusion paths and enhances the accessibility of catalytic active sites. Controlled incorporation of Y nanocrystals enriches acidic sites and optimizes metal-support interaction. Moreover, [Ni(en)3](NO3)2 is used as the nickel precursor further improves metal dispersion, maximizing hydrogenation sites. Consequently, the optimized Ni/YD achieves 93.4 % naphthalene conversion with >65 % BTX yield, exhibiting superior kinetics (reaction rate constant of 1.9 h−1 and turnover frequency of 33.7 h−1). Based on the proposed reaction pathway, appropriate acidity, open dendritic pores and highly dispersed Ni species synergistically promote the isomerization-cracking route selectivity and directed hydrocracking of naphthalene.

coredata.dc:title: Preparation and optimization of dendritic Ni/Y-silica composite catalysts for naphthalene hydrocracking to BTX
